Everybody else.

>> I mean, you know, if
there's one thing better

during a thunderstorm,

it's holding a wire attached
to the top of a tree
during a thunderstorm.
>> Or electrifyingly connect your table
that everyone's sitting at--
>> Yeah
>> To an antenna that's thrown in a tree.

>> Somebody's going to get radio
powers, and I hope it's me.
I don't know what that means.
>> And on that day I became Radio Man.
Let's get radioactive!
I got a whole franchise worked out.
>> All right we're back with Josh Nas
from Ham Radio Crash Course.
>> Thank you.

>> All right, we started off
learning the fundamentals

of short wave radio, how it's
different from AM and FM.

We learned about the
licensing requirements
in order to be able to transmit,

and how you can transmit
as loud as you want
once you're one of the cool kids.
>> Within rules, yeah.

>> Before we even met
you, we had learned about

the fundamentals of transmitting
data images through SSTV.
>> JOSH: Yep. Yep.

>> Which is only one of, there's
multiple protocols I assume.

>> Yeah, there's different
ways to send images.
SSTV is just kind of an umbrella term.
>> We can send something via email.

>> We can use the radio, similar
tones, to send out email.

And ships, when they're
going transcontinental,
just hobbyists, like out sailing,

they use this system to
send word to their family
that they're okay.

>> Now give us the basics
as to how it actually works.

>> Right. So it's taking the
data format of the email,

and it's turning it into
an audio tone basically.

>> I understand that part.
That's just straight up modems,

but I can go out in
the middle of the ocean
and shout in a radio tone.
I don't understand how it ends up
being an email in somebody's --
>> Sure.
>> He does it all the time.
[higher pitched squeaking]
>> Yeah.

>> Then all the dolphins
come, and it's weird.
>> So we basically take the data packet,

and transmit it over the
air in that modem tone.

The receiving station
can either then take it
and connect it to the internet,
in, like, a gateway kind of sense,
or we can go pier to pier.
We can go from station to station
until it gets to the destination.
>> By its very nature,
shouldn't it be a two-way communication?

Does the receiver's stations
say message received? Or--
>> Yes.
>> it just listens?

>> So it's actually a
series of handshakes,

so I'm going to call out to
the receiving station and say,
"I have an email."

And they'll send back, "I'm
ready to receive your email,"
and it's a series of acknowledgments.

>> Do other ships
participate in the network?
Like out at sea?

>> I have not seen
that, but it's possible.

>> That would makes
sense, wouldn't it? Yeah.
>> That seems kind of like a no-brainer.
>> BRIAN: Yeah, right?
>> There are digital modes
that are specifically designed for that.
We have mesh networking, for example,

that we can kind of,
like, create these nodes
and extend them.
One of them is just like a chat program
What we can boop, boop, boop,

and it'll send it across
and through other stations
to get back to the original --
>> You're just adding links in the chains.
You can kind of hot potato this message.

>> You're adding links,
but you're also adding time

because it's not like the
internet or your phone
at a high frequency.
These are lower frequencies,
so this data is going to be slower.
It takes longer to send that data out.
>> Who pays for this?

Is this all done out of
the good will of the hearts
of the people who run the stations?
>> It is, yeah.
This is all manned by amateurs.

That's what amateur radio really
means is non-professional.

We're not paid to do this.
We just do it for fun.
>> Okay, so let's talk about what it takes
to make all this happen.

You have a transceiver,
transmitter and receiver.
>> Right. I'm running a Yaesu FT-891 radio
with an audio interface.

>> BRIAN: Okay, and then we
hung an aerial and a ground--
>> JOSH: Right--
>> BRIAN: So that we're able to set up
a fairly long range reception.

>> Right, and that's called
a half-wave end fed antenna.

>> How do you know which
station that you're looking for?

>> So, I'm using software
called Winlink Express,

and Winlink Express has
a list of all the public
receiving stations and their frequencies,

and you basically kind
of just go down the list
based off of how far it is away from you
until you find one that can receive you.
>> And you know that you have a connection

because you transmit,
"Hey, how's it going?"
>> Yes.

>> And you get back a,
"Hi, I'm receiving you."

>> So much like we did
with the two way radios,
we send out that call sign,

so the computer's sending
out the digital version

of my call saying, "Hey,
are you receiving?"
And it sends back, "Yes, I am. I'm ready."
>> And of course, it's worth noting that

all of this is happening
unencrypted and in public.
>> Yes.

>> So this is not a terribly
secure way to communicate.
>> Right. So, everybody needs to remember

there's no encryption. There's
no secrets in ham radio.
Everything's generally out in the open,

and you could, if you were
so inclined, decode this.

>> I mean, do we just
want to give it a try?
>> Yeah, do you want to leave the room?
>> Yeah, I'll leave the room.
You tell me when I can come back.
>> He's using this as an excuse
to go to the air conditioning.

>> Yeah. Why don't you send
him the missile codes, right?
>> Okay. These are the missile codes.
Grilled cheese.

>> Well, then don't listen!

>> BRIAN: I'm going to leave.
I'm going in the other room!
>> Okay! Go!

Boxcar.

>> JASON: Homecoming.
Contra 2.
Dragon.

we're increasing the

>> Oh, okay.

>> Yeah, so this is fine.
This isn't a big deal,

>> Hey mom. I'm alive.

>> Right.
>> I've posted it to the outbox.

If I click this start button.

[laughing]
>> Do the computers prefer that?
>> No.

>> JASON: When it's going
quiet, that's us transmitting.

>> JOSH: The quiet is
the transmission, yeah.
>> BRIAN: Got it.
[white noise]
>> BRIAN: That's it. Trying to respond.
>> Oh, it said failed though,

so we'll have to do it
again. - [Brian] Okay.
>> JOSH: What we're looking for, too,

is to make sure that nobody
else is using the frequency,
so that could be somebody

>> Somebody else

>> Yeah, I just want to make sure.

Normally it'll tell you a
warning that it's in use.
>> So these receivers, are they low load?
Where they can only take, like,
accept one transmission at a time?
>> Oh, yeah. This is one at a time, yeah.

>> Okay. So we could be in
a queue for all we know?
>> No. It doesn't work that way.
It's a first come, first serve.

>> No, because it's all
talking at the same time.

Like we could DDos them by
just constantly hitting on this
and making noise.
>> Right.
>> Right, and there's no queue to it.

It's when it's open, you go,
and if you get it, you get it.

>> Okay. Actually, it just

The crowd and then the--
>> Oh yeah, yeah.

>> Yeah. Somebody blowing a
whistle for a foul or something.
>> Right, exactly

>> Now it's not responding,
so it's possibly because

it's getting darker on

>> Yeah.

>> That they're just not
able to receive us as well,
so I can change it to closer in,
which closer in sometimes may not be good
depending on how your antenna is laid out.
>> Got it.

>> Oddly enough. So this
one also doesn't look
like it's replying.

This is kind of generally
what this game is
is you have to kind of call out

until you get someone
that responds to you,
and then you complete your contact.
[whitenoise]
>> That's CW. That's morse code.
>> Oh. Got it.

>> Somebody's just in
the space foolin around.
>> Just happens to be there.
>> Yeah because we're allowed to use it
for whatever we want. This isn't --
>> It's not reserved.
>> For Winlink.
>> There's no telling anyone, Yeah.

>> It's generally good
form, since he was calling,
to give him a little bit of time
before you try and then throw your email--
>> Got it.

>> On top of him. So, it's just
wide open in the air, right?

So he could be on here for
minutes, hours, I don't know.

So, generally that's why
you hop around a little bit

until you find something
that's clear and in the open.

When we go back to this
channel selection screen,
the reliability with the green
is kind of the stations I'm looking at.
>> BRIAN: Got it.
>> JOSH: I'm looking for the green,

and not so much the yellows,
and definitely not the reds.
>> JASON: Sure.
>> BRIAN: In theory I have to imagine

that there's some version of
this that's just scripted,
and we'll automatically keep trying.

>> Yes and no. It doesn't want
you to automatically retry.
It wants a command operator in the loop.
>> Oh, because otherwise,

it's just going to put
a bunch of noise, yeah.

>> Yeah. There are some within
the amateur radio community
that actually don't like Winlink.
>> Oh, really?
>> They don't like people using email
because they think it's too encoded,
so there are some nefarious type people

that will actually go into
these frequency spaces--

>> And jam.

>> To keep the software

radio frequency purists,

>> The sanctity of radio.
>> Wouldn't that get your license revoked
if they knew it was you?
>> If they found-- -Yeah.

>> Or you know, yes. Yes.
Across the board, so okay.
Yeah, see there's somebody else in there.

to be an actual communication?
>> It is, but it's not email.
They're using something called RTTY
which is radio teletype.
>> Okay. - And that's just a chatroom.
They're just chatting back and forth.
>> Oh, so who knows how long that's--

>> We have no idea. They
could just be doing field day.
Because field day is just open,
so they're just doing whatever they--
>> Yeah.
>> JASON: What about this 179 here?

I don't really want to use

>> That I'm transmitting on,
the power that I'm trying to output

[siren]
